Are we losing the evolutionary arms race?

23/08/2012

The evolution of a superbug capable of wiping out a large proportion of the population is currently highly speculative but we have seen multiple examples on a smaller scale in recent decades, says Ashley Ferro. (Thumbnail credit Photo Credit: gardinergirl)

Image by

By undefined undefined

The role of 'natural selection' as a mechanism of evolution was first proposed in 1859 by Charles Darwin in perhaps his most influential piece, 'The Origin of Species'. Darwin's work on species diversity from the early voyage on the HMS Beagle provided what many consider as irrefutable evidence for evolution. It transformed thinking on mechanisms underpinning the emergence of species. The simplest way to define natural selection is to say that the environment acts as a filter, reducing the abundance of 'less favourable' traits throughout a population by preventing their hosts from reproducing. The mechanism is heavily dependent upon genetic variation between members of a population - differences in the 'building blocks' of our DNA which define our phenotype (physical attributes dictated by our genes). The phenotypic differences between members of a population give rise to the well-known phrase 'survival of the fittest'. Those which are best adapted to the surrounding environmental conditions (have the greatest fitness) are more likely to reproduce, passing on these beneficial traits to the next generation. Similarly, this means that deleterious mutations (those which reduce the fitness of an individual) are lost from the population as the chance of successful reproduction is reduced - such mutations are said to be 'selected against' by this environmental filter. Of course, natural selection is not the only driving force of evolution, but it has proved an elementary concept in our ability to truly comprehend how such complex entities as humans could arise from primitive beginnings. 'Fitness' ensures that less favourable traits are selected against, such that evolution is continually driven in a 'forward' direction to generate beings that are just slightly better adapted to survival than those of the previous generation. But what if the differences in fitness are artificially negated, so that the chance of reaching reproductive maturity is equal for all members of a population? Surely, evolution would grind to an unrelenting halt where deleterious mutations are allowed to remain within the population, and the selecting actions of the environment fail to remove the least fit individuals. There is currently speculation that this may be the case for humans. The marvellously complex brains which evolution has given us have facilitated the development of complex technologies and medical innovations. In many cases, deleterious mutations that once would have significantly impaired an individual's survival now have very little influence due to an abundance of medication and the availability to nutrient-rich foods. It is thought, therefore, that selection pressures against such deleterious mutations may become relinquished; potentially resulting in an increased incidence of heritable disease. A further complication of reduced human evolution involves susceptibility to bacterial infection. As covered in a previous Nouse Science article, antibiotic resistance is becoming a persisting problem in medicine. Our ability to evade death from infection and disease is partially dependent upon an evolutionary 'battle' pitting human defences against microbial and pathogenic factors. For example, we have evolved an adaptive immune system involving lymphocytes (white blood cells) and antibodies. In response, some bacteria have evolved mechanisms to evade detection, such as the secretion of 'protein A' in Staphyloccocus aureus which indirectly prevents bacterial phagocytosis (engulfment) by innate immune cells. The enhanced rate of bacterial evolution and resistance resulting from persistent exploitation of antibiotics, in accordance with a reduced rate of human evolution through medical intervention, simply increases our susceptibility to potentially life threatening 'superbugs'. The evolution of a superbug capable of wiping out a large proportion of the population is currently highly speculative but we have seen multiple examples on a smaller scale in recent decades, including 'Vancomycin resistant Staphylococcus aureus' and, more recently, 'extensively drug resistant Mycobacterium tuberculosis'. It appears as though the evolutionary gift of superior intellect may have impaired the extent of further human evolution, prompting a veritable concern for our survival in future decades.
